text: John Singer Sargent (/ˈsɑːrdʒənt/; January 12, 1856 – April 14, 1925)[1] was an American expatriate artist, considered the "leading portrait painter of his generation" for his evocations of Edwardian-era luxury.[2][3] He created roughly 900 oil paintings and more than 2,000 watercolors, as well as countless sketches and charcoal drawings. His oeuvre documents worldwide travel, from Venice to the Tyrol, Corfu, Spain, the Middle East, Montana, Maine, and Florida.
statement:
```
MERGE (p:Person {name: 'John Singer Sargent'})
MERGE (c1:City {name: 'Venice'})
MERGE (c2:City {name: 'Tyrol'})
MERGE (c3:City {name: 'Corfu'})
MERGE (c4:City {name: 'Spain'})
MERGE (c5:City {name: 'Middle East'})
MERGE (c6:City {name: 'Montana'})
MERGE (c7:City {name: 'Maine'})
MERGE (c8:City {name: 'Florida'})
MERGE (a1:Artwork {type: 'oil painting'})
MERGE (a2:Artwork {type: 'watercolor'})
MERGE (a3:Artwork {type: 'sketch'})
MERGE (a4:Artwork {type: 'charcoal drawing'})
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(c1)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(c2)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(c3)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(c4)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(c5)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(c6)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(c7)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(c8)
MERGE (p)-[:CREATED]->(a1)
MERGE (p)-[:CREATED]->(a2)
MERGE (p)-[:CREATED]->(a3)
MERGE (p)-[:CREATED]->(a4)
```

text: Lyman Frank Baum (/bɔːm/;[1] May 15, 1856 – May 6, 1919) was an American author best known for his children's fantasy books, particularly The Wonderful Wizard of Oz, part of a series. In addition to the 14 Oz books, Baum penned 41 other novels (not including four lost, unpublished novels), 83 short stories, over 200 poems, and at least 42 scripts. He made numerous attempts to bring his works to the stage and screen; the 1939 adaptation of the first Oz book became a landmark of 20th-century cinema.
statement:
```
MERGE (p:Person {name: 'Lyman Frank Baum', dob: 'May 15, 1856', dod: 'May 6, 1919', nationality: 'American'})
MERGE (b:Book {name: 'The Wonderful Wizard of Oz'})
MERGE (s:Series {name: 'Oz'})
MERGE (c:Cinema {name: '1939 adaptation of the first Oz book', year: 1939})
MERGE (p)-[:AUTHORED]->(b)
MERGE (b)-[:PART_OF]->(s)
MERGE (p)-[:ATTEMPTED]->(:Adaptation {name: 'Stage and Screen Adaptation'})
MERGE (c)-[:ADAPTATION_OF]->(b)
```

text: John Davison Rockefeller III (March 21, 1906 – July 10, 1978) was an American philanthropist. Rockefeller was the eldest son and second child of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller as well as a grandson of Standard Oil co-founder John D. Rockefeller. He was engaged in a wide range of philanthropic projects, many of which his family had launched, as well as supporting organizations related to East Asian affairs. Rockefeller was also a major supporter of the Population Council, and the committee that created the Lincoln Center in Manhattan.
statement:
```
MERGE (jdr3:Person {name: 'John Davison Rockefeller III'})
MERGE (jdrjr:Person {name: 'John D. Rockefeller Jr.'})
MERGE (aar:Person {name: 'Abby Aldrich Rockefeller'})
MERGE (jdr:Person {name: 'John D. Rockefeller'})
MERGE (so:Company {name: 'Standard Oil'})
MERGE (pc:Council {name: 'Population Council'})
MERGE (lc:Center {name: 'Lincoln Center'})
MERGE (ea:Affairs {name: 'East Asian affairs'})
MERGE (jdr3)-[:SON_OF]->(jdrjr)
MERGE (jdr3)-[:SON_OF]->(aar)
MERGE (jdr3)-[:GRANDSON_OF]->(jdr)
MERGE (jdr3)-[:SUPPORTER_OF]->(pc)
MERGE (jdr3)-[:SUPPORTER_OF]->(lc)
MERGE (jdr3)-[:RELATED_TO]->(ea)
MERGE (jdr)-[:CO_FOUNDER_OF]->(so)
```

text: Samuel Langhorne Clemens (November 30, 1835 – April 21, 1910),[1] known by the pen name Mark Twain, was an American writer, humorist and essayist. He was praised as the "greatest humorist the United States has produced,"[2] with William Faulkner calling him "the father of American literature."[3] His novels include The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (1876) and its sequel, Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1884),[4] with the latter often called the "Great American Novel." Twain also wrote A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court (1889) and Pudd'nhead Wilson (1894), and co-wrote The Gilded Age: A Tale of Today (1873) with Charles Dudley Warner.
statement:
```
MERGE (p:Person {name: 'Samuel Langhorne Clemens', dob: '1835-11-30', dod: '1910-04-21', penName: 'Mark Twain'})
MERGE (c:Country {name: 'United States'})
MERGE (p)-[:IS_FROM]->(c)
MERGE (w:Writer {name: 'William Faulkner'})
MERGE (w)-[:CALLED {description: 'the father of American literature'}]->(p)
MERGE (b1:Book {name: 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer', year: 1876})
MERGE (b2:Book {name: 'Adventures of Huckleberry Finn', year: 1884})
MERGE (b3:Book {name: 'A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur\'s Court', year: 1889})
MERGE (b4:Book {name: 'Pudd\'nhead Wilson', year: 1894})
MERGE (b5:Book {name: 'The Gilded Age: A Tale of Today', year: 1873})
MERGE (p)-[:WROTE]->(b1)
MERGE (p)-[:WROTE]->(b2)
MERGE (p)-[:WROTE]->(b3)
MERGE (p)-[:WROTE]->(b4)
MERGE (p)-[:CO_WROTE {with: 'Charles Dudley Warner'}]->(b5)
```

text: Henry Huttleston Rogers (January 29, 1840 – May 19, 1909) was an American industrialist and financier. He made his fortune in the oil refining business, becoming a leader at Standard Oil. He also played a major role in numerous corporations and business enterprises in the gas industry, copper, and railroads. He became a close friend of Mark Twain.
statement:
```
MERGE (p1:Person {name: 'Henry Huttleston Rogers', dob: 'January 29, 1840', dod: 'May 19, 1909', occupation: 'Industrialist and Financier'})
MERGE (p2:Person {name: 'Mark Twain'})
MERGE (c:Company {name: 'Standard Oil'})
MERGE (i:Industry {name: 'Oil Refining'})
MERGE (i2:Industry {name: 'Gas'})
MERGE (i3:Industry {name: 'Copper'})
MERGE (i4:Industry {name: 'Railroads'})
MERGE (p1)-[:MADE_FORTUNE_IN]->(i)
MERGE (p1)-[:BECAME_LEADER_AT]->(c)
MERGE (p1)-[:PLAYED_MAJOR_ROLE_IN]->(i2)
MERGE (p1)-[:PLAYED_MAJOR_ROLE_IN]->(i3)
MERGE (p1)-[:PLAYED_MAJOR_ROLE_IN]->(i4)
MERGE (p1)-[:FRIEND_OF]->(p2)
```

text: John Pierpont Morgan (April 17, 1837 – March 31, 1913)[1] was an American financier and investment banker who dominated corporate finance on Wall Street throughout the Gilded Age and Progressive Era. As the head of the banking firm that ultimately became known as J.P. Morgan and Co., he was a driving personal force behind the wave of industrial consolidations in the United States at the turn of the twentieth century.
statement:
```
MERGE (p:Person {name: 'John Pierpont Morgan', birthDate: 'April 17, 1837', deathDate: 'March 31, 1913', nationality: 'American', profession: 'financier and investment banker'})
MERGE (c:Company {name: 'J.P. Morgan and Co.'})
MERGE (e:Event {name: 'Industrial consolidations in the United States at the turn of the twentieth century'})
MERGE (p)-[:HEAD_OF]->(c)
MERGE (p)-[:INFLUENCED]->(e)
```

text: John Charles Frémont or Fremont (January 21, 1813 – July 13, 1890) was an American explorer, military officer, and politician. He was a United States senator from California and was the first Republican nominee for president of the U.S. in 1856 and founder of the California Republican Party when he was nominated. He lost the election to Democrat James Buchanan when the vote was split by Know Nothings.
statement:
```
MERGE (p:Person {name: 'John Charles Frémont', birthdate: '1813-01-21', deathdate: '1890-07-13'})
MERGE (c:Country {name: 'United States'})
MERGE (s:State {name: 'California'})
MERGE (pp:PoliticalParty {name: 'Republican Party'})
MERGE (e:Election {year: 1856})
MERGE (op:Person {name: 'James Buchanan'})
MERGE (p)-[:ROLE]->(:Role {name: 'Explorer'})
MERGE (p)-[:ROLE]->(:Role {name: 'Military Officer'})
MERGE (p)-[:ROLE]->(:Role {name: 'Politician'})
MERGE (p)-[:SENATOR_FROM]->(s)
MERGE (s)-[:PART_OF]->(c)
MERGE (p)-[:NOMINEE_FOR {party: 'Republican', year: 1856}]->(pp)
MERGE (p)-[:FOUNDER_OF]->(:PoliticalParty {name: 'California Republican Party'})
MERGE (p)-[:LOST_TO]->(op)
MERGE (op)-[:WON]->(e)
```

text: Geronimo (Mescalero-Chiricahua: Goyaałé, Athapascan pronunciation: [kòjàːɬɛ́], lit. 'the one who yawns'; June 16, 1829 – February 17, 1909) was a military leader and medicine man from the Bedonkohe band of the Ndendahe Apache people. From 1850 to 1886, Geronimo joined with members of three other Central Apache bands – the Tchihende, the Tsokanende (called Chiricahua by Americans) and the Nednhi – to carry out numerous raids, as well as fight against Mexican and U.S. military campaigns in the northern Mexico states of Chihuahua and Sonora and in the southwestern American territories of New Mexico and Arizona.
statement:
```
MERGE (p:Person {name: 'Geronimo', birthdate: '1829-06-16', deathdate: '1909-02-17', nationality: 'Apache'})

MERGE (s2:State {name: 'Sonora'})
MERGE (c2:Country {name: 'United States'})
MERGE (s3:State {name: 'New Mexico'})
MERGE (s4:State {name: 'Arizona'})
MERGE (b1:Band {name: 'Bedonkohe'})
MERGE (b2:Band {name: 'Tchihende'})
MERGE (b3:Band {name: 'Tsokanende'})
MERGE (b4:Band {name: 'Nednhi'})
MERGE (p)-[:IS_FROM]->(b1)
MERGE (p)-[:RELATED_TO]->(b2)
MERGE (p)-[:RELATED_TO]->(b3)
MERGE (p)-[:RELATED_TO]->(b4)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(s1)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(s2)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(s3)
MERGE (p)-[:TRAVELED_TO]->(s4)
```
